III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Lotus Treatment Program is a 28-bed facility that is located within the Child and
Adolescent building on the Pine Rest Campus in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Lotus
Treatment Program is a secure program that is one wing of the building. Upon
entry to the Child and Adolescent building there is a receptionist desk for checking
in and gaining entry into the program. Lotus Treatment Program is behind locked
doors and access is only granted through a staff member. Upon entry to the Lotus
Treatment Program wing of the building there is a long hallway that is painted in
bright colors. Lotus Treatment Program is comprised of four units that are set up
exactly the same and all located down the main hallway. The units are across
from each other with Ruby and Violet located first and Jade and Indigo located at
the end of the hallway.
Ruby, Violet, Jade, and Indigo all are rectangular in shape with rooms located on
the perimeter of the unit. As you enter the unit there is a classroom which also has
a second exit door into the main hallway. The classroom will remain locked, and
youth will only be allowed in by staff during school hours. The school is online
through Kentwood Schools and each youth will be provided a computer to use
throughout the school day and it will remain in the classroom at all times.
2

Opposite the classroom is a door that leads into a visit area for youth to use for
private visits. There is a second door off the visit room that leads into another
room that can be used as a second visit area or a conference area. Within the unit
as you walk further in past the classroom door there is a laundry room that is
locked and will only be accessed by staff to complete the laundry for the youth.
Opposite the laundry room is a small code closet that is locked and contains two
code buttons that will only be used by staff in emergency situations to notify the
main switchboard operator if needed. As you enter further into the unit there is a
medication room that will remain locked and only accessed by staff. On the same
side as the medication room are three bedrooms and the recreational therapist
office. On the wall opposite the medication room there are four bedrooms and a
social workers office. The recreational therapist and social workers office will
remain locked unless staff are working in those areas. Each bedroom contains a
bed that is secured to the floor, a shelving unit that is secured to the wall, and a
bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. At the end of the unit is a staff office and
a sensory room. The middle area of each unit has half of the room set up with
dining room tables that are secured to the ground, a cabinet unit that stretches the
width of the room which will hold supplies for the youth, and the other half set up
with individual chairs and a television that is secured to the wall behind plexiglass.
In the main hallway the units are located off, includes several additional rooms.
These rooms include two bathrooms, two rooms for housekeeping supplies, a
conference room, a staff room used to secure their belongings, a supervisor’s
offices, a nutritional room, hygiene storage area, and another visit room.
An Environmental Health Inspection occurred on May 26, 2023, and resulted in an
“A” rating, as did the Fire Safety Inspection conducted on May 17, 2023. The
Gaines Charter Township of Kent County approved the facility to be zoned for the
capacity of 40 on June 1, 2023. The facility does not have cameras as they accept
youth through Community Mental Health programs.
B. Program Description
The Lotus Program is part of Pine Rest’s continuum of care, providing intensive
community transition services for males and females, ages 11-17 in a secure
setting. The facility is being licensed for 28 total youth, with 7 youth being allowed
in each unit. The program is designed to develop and enhance psychiatric
stability, emotional stabilization, self-sufficiency, skills to live in a more
independent setting, and the requisition and establishment of needed community-
based behavioral health services. Youth may be referred and funded by the
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services or Community Mental Health
organizations. The staff-to-resident ratio will be 1:3 during waking hours and 2:7
during sleeping hours.
The Lotus Program is designed to provide time-limited behavioral health services
and supports due to risk of significant functional deterioration if services are not
provided. Individualized treatment planning is designed to develop and enhance
psychiatric stability, personal and emotional stabilization, self-sufficiency, skills to
3

live in a more independent setting, requisition and establishment of needed
community-based behavioral health services. Each youth will have a treatment
plan with specified outcomes that is consistent with evidence-based practices
related to their individualized needs and a targeted discharge date. The
foundation of the program is based on the D.R.I.V.E Challenge® Foundation. The
D.R.I.V.E Focus Clinical Program is focused on developing skills in the areas of
self-discipline, respect, integrity, vision, and excellence. The environment as well
as the treatment team are trained in trauma informed care, diversity, equity and
inclusion as well as the Restorative Approach to relationship building.
Programming services are completed by Recreational Therapists, Occupational
Therapy clinicians, in addition to Clinical Therapists and Psychiatric Technicians.
Programming includes independent living skills development, education
surrounding emotional, mental and physical wellbeing, in addition to development
surrounding social skills, relationships and within the context of education. The
program provides individualized treatment that promotes safety, trust and peer
support that is collaborative in nature that empowers resiliency and choice
through restorative approaches.
All youth have a master’s level therapist assigned. Each youth also has an
attending psychiatrist and general medical provider who provides medication
management and primary care services at individualized intervals. Each youth
has regular and active nursing care and the nurse (RN) functions as the liaison
between the psychiatrist and the treatment team. The nurses, therapists, and
program supervisors meet regularly with the psychiatrist to maintain updates
surrounding overall treatment and to ensure ongoing and active psychiatric care.
Individual therapy, group therapy, and family therapy or consultation with outside
caseworkers is included in the treatment planning. Activity therapy and education
are all part of the ongoing care of the youth. Staff are trained in the use of Safety-
Care, Behavioral Safety Training program, QBS for de-escalation and restraint.
Education for youth admitted to the Lotus Treatment Program is provided by the
East Kentwood Intermediate School District. Dental and vision care are provided.
A variety of other services are offered on a consultation and as needed basis,
such as behavioral supports with a Board-Certified Behavioral Analyst (BCBA)
and behavioral technicians as well as nutrition assessment with a Dietician.
Pharmaceutical services are provided through IPS Inpatient Pharmacy
conveniently located on the Pine Rest campus. Lab and dietary services are
based on contractual arrangements with Forefront and Metro Health. Emergent
medical care is sought at times through local emergency centers; general medical
care is through the Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Services Pediatric and
General Medicine Department.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The agency was found in compliance.

Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
